case_name: ex-jagirdar of Jagir Nevri Bhorasa v. State

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 98 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 98 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Madhya Pradesh High Court Gwalior Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the December 7, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Ben

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court Gwalior Bench delivered judgment and order dated December 7, 1961 in Civil Misc. Petition No. 77 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the December 7, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Bench  in Civil Misc. Petition No. 77 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellant is the ex-jagirdar of villages called Jagir Nevri Bhorasa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the ex-jagirdar of certain villages called Jagir Nevri Bhorasa.

facts.text: Appellant constructed a road connecting Bhorasa with Dewas Astha Road while jagir was in his possession.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that while the jagir was in his possession he had companystructed roads one of which is the road companynecting Bhorasa with Dewas Astha Road.

facts.text: The road is about 1 1/2 miles in length and lined on both sides with mango trees.

anchor.surface_text: The road about 1 1/2 miles in length was lined on both sides with mango trees.

facts.text: Madhya Bharat Abolition of Jagirs Act, 28 of 1951 was passed in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951 the Madhya Bharat Abolition of Jagirs Act, 28 of 1951  hereinafter referred to as the Act  was passed for resumption of jagir lands in the State.

facts.text: Under the Act, appellant's right, title and interest in jagir extinguished and jagir lands vested in the State.

anchor.surface_text: Under that Act, the right, title and interest of the appellant in his said jagir were extinguished and the jagir lands vested in the State.

facts.text: In 1955, Tehsildar put up mangoes grown on the trees for public auction.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, the Tehsildar put up the mangoes grown on the said trees for public auction.

facts.text: Appellant filed application dated February 8, 1955 objecting to auction.

anchor.surface_text: By his application dated February 8, 1955 the appellant objected to the said auction claiming that the said trees were planted and reared by him,

facts.text: Appellant claimed trees were planted and reared by him and constituted a grove under s.5(b)(iv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By his application dated February 8, 1955 the appellant objected to the said auction claiming that the said trees were planted and reared by him, that they companystituted a grove within the meaning of s. 5 b  iv  of the Act

facts.text: Tehsildar rejected appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: The Tehsildar rejected the application.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal against Tehsildar order was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants appeal and thereafter a revision before the Board of Revenue were also likewise rejected.

facts.text: Appellant's revision before Board of Revenue was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants appeal and thereafter a revision before the Board of Revenue were also likewise rejected.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Madhya Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh but that also was dismissed

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed writ petition on ground that trees could not constitute a grove.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh but that also was dismissed on the ground that the said trees companyld number be said to companystitute a grove.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has filed this appeal after obtaining special leave.

facts.text: Trees are standing on two sides of the road.

anchor.surface_text: The road about 1 1/2 miles in length was lined on both sides with mango trees.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, and remanded case to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed, the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the case is remanded to the High Court to decide the writ petition in the light of the observations hereinabove made

facts.text: Supreme Court directed High Court to call finding from Board of Revenue on whether trees at any place along road constitute grove.

anchor.surface_text: after calling a finding from the Board of Revenue on the question whether there are trees at any place or places along the said road sufficient in number and proximity to companystitute a grove or groves.

facts.text: Board of Revenue to give opportunity to parties to adduce evidence on whether trees constitute grove.

anchor.surface_text: The Board will give an opportunity to the parties to adduce on the aforesaid question such further evidence, as they may think necessary.

facts.text: Revenue authorities and High Court dismissed claim because trees stand along two sides of road.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the revenue authorities number the High Court approached the question from this point of view and numberinquiry at any stage seems to have been made whether there are at any place or places such group or groups of trees to companystitute a grove or groves.

facts.text: Trees are mango trees.

anchor.surface_text: The road about 1 1/2 miles in length was lined on both sides with mango trees.
Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the December 7, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Ben
The appellant then filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh but that also was dismissed on the ground that the said trees could not be said to constitute a grove.
In 1951 the Madhya Bharat Abolition of Jagirs Act, 28 of 1951  hereinafter referred to as the Act  was passed for resumption of jagir lands in the State.

anchor.surface_text: The only question arising in this appeal is whether the said trees standing on the two sides of the said road can be said to be a grove within the meaning of sec. 5 b  iv .

anchor.surface_text: By his application dated February 8, 1955 the appellant objected to the said auction claiming that the said trees were planted and reared by him, that they constituted a grove within the meaning of s. 5 b  iv  of the Act and therefore continued to belong to him.

arguments.claim: The said trees could not be said to constitute a grove

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh but that also was dismissed on the ground that the said trees could not be said to constitute a grove.

arguments.court_reasoning: Authorities and High Court failed to inquire if groups of trees at places constitute grove

arguments.claim: Although trees are on road sides, there may be groups at some places sufficiently large and close to constitute a grove, and nothing prevents such cluster from being a grove

anchor.surface_text: Counsel, however, contended that although the trees in question are situate on the road sides along the said road there may at some places be a group or groups of trees sufficiently large in number and closely standing together to preclude that particular area from being used for cultivation or for any other purpose.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: by a cluster of trees specially planted by human agency but number large enough to companystitute a forest. It would seem therefore that the word grov

arguments.court_reasoning: Some force in argument, requires consideration; remand for evidence

arguments.claim: The word 'trees' used in different senses in secs. 4(a), 5(b), 5(c); to be construed in context

anchor.surface_text: These provisions show clearly that the legislature has used the word trees at three places in three different contexts, in secs. 4 a , 5 b  and 5 c  apart from the expression all groves wherever situate in sub-cl.  iv  of sec. 5 b . Whereas under sec. 4 a  the trees are to vest in the State Government

arguments.claim: Legislative policy: resume public use properties like forests, trees in forests; retain personal cultivation lands, enclosures, house-sites, trees thereon, groves

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, the word trees in these provisions has not been used in any uniform sense and therefore has to be construed in the context in which it is used. For instance, the word trees in sec. 5 b  iii  and  c  is placed in juxtaposition with other properties such as private buildings, places of worship, wells situated in lands included in the said enclosures and house sites

arguments.claim: Groves under s.5(b)(iv) continue to belong to jagirdar wherever situate, even if not on retained lands; land appurtenant settled

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen that groves in sub-cl.  iv  of sec.  b  are included amongst properties allowed to continue to belong to and be held by the jagirdar. Subclause  iv  also shows that such groves need not be of fruit trees nor need the trees thereof have been planted by the jagirdar.

arguments.claim: 'Grove' to be understood in ordinary dictionary sense as small wood, group of trees without undergrowth, cluster for shade

anchor.surface_text: What then is the meaning of the word grove within the meaning of sec. 5 b  iv 9 Though the Act contains a definition section the legislature has not chosen to include therein any definition of a grove. It intended therefore that it should be understood in its ordinary dictionary sense.

arguments.claim: In Daropadi v. Mannu Lal, 4 trees on boundaries not a grove (Agra Tenancy Act s.3)

anchor.surface_text: The case of Daropadi v. Mannu Lal 1  was, of course an extreme case of only 4 fruit trees in an area of 3 bighas and that too on the boundaries. Ashworth J. held therefore easily discard the contention that the said trees formed a grove

arguments.claim: In Kashi v. Jagoo Bai, isolated trees not a grove

anchor.surface_text: In Kashi v. Jagoo Bai 2  also, Bennet J. held that isolated trees cannot be said to constitute a grove.

arguments.claim: In Shiv Sahai v. Hari Nandan, 13 mango trees covering major part is grove-land even with some cultivation (P. Tenancy Act s.3(5))

anchor.surface_text: But unlike these two cases, the land in Shiv Sahai Hari Nandan 3  had 13 mango trees fully grown, big in size and covering a major part of it. It was held that the land was a grove-land within the meaning of sec. 3 5  of the P. Tenancy Act, 1939

arguments.claim: In Hasan v. State of Bombay, grove is cluster of trees specially planted but not forest (MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act s.5(h))

anchor.surface_text: In Hasan v. State of Bombay 1  the High Court was concerned with s. 5 h  of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietory Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1 of 1951 which is in almost identical terms as S. 5 b  iv  of the present Act.

arguments.claim: Grove conveys compactness, group of trees sufficient in number and proximity to preclude land from primary use other than grove-land

anchor.surface_text: It would seem therefore that the word grove conveys compactness or at any rate substantial compactness to be recognized as a unit by itself which must consist of a group of trees in sufficient number to preclude the land on which they stand from being primarily used for a purpose, such as cultivation, other than as a grove-land.

arguments.claim: Trees standing in a file on road side for shade do not constitute a grove

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, trees standing in a file on the road sidle intended to furnish shade to the road would not fulfil the requirements of a grove even as understood in ordinary parlance.

arguments.claim: Revenue authorities and High Court erred by not inquiring if there are groups of trees at places constituting grove

anchor.surface_text: Neither the revenue authorities nor the High Court approached the question from this point of view and no inquiry at any stage seems to have been made whether there are at any place or places such group or groups of trees to constitute a grove or groves.

holdings.text: The word 'trees' in sections 4(a), 5(b) and 5(c) of the Act has not been used in any uniform sense and therefore has to be construed in the context in which it is used.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, the word trees in these provisions has not been used in any uniform sense and therefore has to be construed in the context in which it is used. For instance, the word trees in sec. 5 b  iii  and  c  is placed in juxtaposition with other properties such as private buildings, places of worship, wells situated in lands included in the said enclosures and house sites

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature used 'trees' in different contexts: vesting in State under s.4(a) vs retention under s.5(b),(c); harmonious construction required.

holdings.text: Groves under s.5(b)(iv) continue to belong to or be held by the jagirdar wherever situate, regardless of whether on retained lands, and appurtenant land shall be settled by Government.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen that groves in sub-cl.  iv  of sec.  b  are included amongst properties allowed to continue to belong to and be held by the jagirdar. Subclause  iv  also shows that such groves need not be of fruit trees nor need the trees thereof have been planted by the jagirdar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.5(b)(iv) uses 'wherever situate'; distinguishes from other retained properties; purposive policy to retain personal use properties.

holdings.text: The word 'grove' in s.5(b)(iv) bears its ordinary dictionary meaning: a small wood or group of trees standing together without undergrowth, a cluster affording shade.

anchor.surface_text: What then is the meaning of the word grove within the meaning of sec. 5 b  iv 9 Though the Act contains a definition section the legislature has not chosen to include therein any definition of a grove. It intended therefore that it should be understood in its ordinary dictionary sense. In Websters New World Dictionary, p. 641, a grove has been defined as a small wood groups of trees standing together without undergrowth.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory definition; legislature intended ordinary sense; cites Webster's, Oxford, Corpus Juris Secundum.

holdings.text: A 'grove' conveys compactness or substantial compactness, consisting of a group of trees sufficient in number and proximity to preclude the land from being primarily used for cultivation or other non-grove purpose.

anchor.surface_text: It would seem therefore that the word grove conveys compactness or at any rate substantial compactness to be recognized as a unit by itself which must consist of a group of trees in sufficient number to preclude the land on which they stand from being primarily used for a purpose, such as cultivation, other than as a grove-land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesizes dictionary meanings with precedents (Daropadi, Kashi, Shiv Sahai, Hasan) defining grove as cluster not forest, precluding other uses.

holdings.text: s.5(b)(iv) does not require groves to consist of fruit-bearing trees or trees planted by the jagirdar.

anchor.surface_text: Subclause  iv  also shows that such groves need not be of fruit trees nor need the trees thereof have been planted by the jagirdar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of provision; no such qualifiers in text.

holdings.text: Trees standing in a file on the roadside intended to furnish shade to the road do not constitute a grove.

anchor.surface_text: The language of sec. 5 b  iv  does not require however that the trees needs be fruit bearing trees nor does it require that they should have been planted by human labour or agency. But they must be sufficient in number and so standing in a group as to give them the character of a grove ... Therefore, trees standing in a file on the road sidle intended to furnish shade to the road would not fulfil the requirements of a grove even as understood in ordinary parlance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of grove test: linear avenue trees lack compactness and do not preclude other land use.

holdings.text: Roadside trees may constitute a grove if at any place or places there are groups sufficient in number and proximity; s.5(b)(iv) does not prevent such clusters from being groves.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel, however, contended that although the trees in question are situate on the road sides along the said road there may at some places be a group or groups of trees sufficiently large in number and closely standing together to preclude that particular area from being used for cultivation or for any other purpose. In that case, be argued, there was nothing in subcl.  iv  to prevent such a cluster of trees from being regarded as a grove. We think there is some force in this argument which requires consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's contention has force; applies grove test to possible factual clusters.

holdings.text: Revenue authorities and High Court erred by dismissing claim solely because trees stand along two sides of road, without inquiring if groups at places constitute grove.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the revenue authorities nor the High Court approached the question from this point of view and no inquiry at any stage seems to have been made whether there are at any place or places such group or groups of trees to constitute a grove or groves. All of them appear to have dismissed the appellants claim only because of the fact that the trees stand along the two sides of the road.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failed to apply correct test; no evidence-based inquiry on clusters.

holdings.text: High Court writ dismissal set aside; case remanded to decide after Board of Revenue finding on whether trees at places along road sufficient to constitute grove, with opportunity to adduce evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural fairness requires fact-finding under correct legal test; parties' right to evidence.

It was held that the land was a grove-land within the meaning of sec. 3 5  of the P. Tenancy Act, 1939,

precedents.cited_proposition: isolated trees do not constitute a grove
precedents.cited_holding: isolated trees cannot be said to constitute a grove

precedents.citation: Shiv Sahai Hari Nandan 3 A.I.R. 1963 All 413

anchor.surface_text: But unlike these two cases, the land in Shiv Sahai Hari Nandan 3  had 13 mango trees fully grown, big in size and companyering a major part of it. It was held that the land was a grove-land within the meaning of sec. 3 5  of the P. Tenancy Act, 1939, in spite of the fact that there was some cultivation on the land. The Court there observed that the definition merely A.I.R. 1929 All 557  2  A.I.R. 1934 All 290. A.I.R. 1963 All 413. required that the trees must be in sufficiently large number to preclude the land from being used primarily for a purpose other than as grove-land.

precedents.cited_proposition: sufficiently large number of trees preclude land from primary use other than grove-land, even with some cultivation
precedents.cited_holding: land with 13 fully grown mango trees covering major part is grove-land under P. Tenancy Act despite some cultivation

precedents.citation: Hasan v. State of Bombay 1 62 Bom. L.R. 617

anchor.surface_text: In Hasan v. State of Bombay 1  the High Court was companycerned with s. 5 h  of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietory Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1 of 1951 which is in almost identical terms as S. 5 b  iv  of the present Act. The Court interpreted the word grove to mean an area companyered by a cluster of trees specially planted by human agency but number large enough to companystitute a forest.

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'grove' under similar provision as cluster of trees specially planted by human agency but not constituting a forest
precedents.cited_holding: grove means an area covered by a cluster of trees specially planted by human agency but not large enough to constitute a forest

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, the word trees in these provisions has not been used in any uniform sense and therefore has to be construed in the context in which it is used. For instance, the word trees in sec. 5 b  iii  and  c  is placed in juxtaposition with other properties such as private buildings, places of worship, wells situated in lands included in the said enclosures and house sites

The appeal is allowed, the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the case is remanded to the High Court to decide the writ petition in the light of the observations hereinabove made after calling a finding from the Board of Revenue on the question whether there are trees at any place or places along the said road s

anchor.surface_text: What then is the meaning of the word grove within the meaning of sec. 5 b  iv 9 Though the Act contains a definition section the legislature has not chosen to include therein any definition of a grove. It intended therefore that it should be understood in its ordinary dictionary sense. In Websters New World Dictionary, p. 641, a grove has been defined as a small wood groups of trees standing together without undergrowth.

The appeal is allowed, the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the case is remanded to the High Court to decide the writ petition in the light of the observations hereinabove made after calling a finding from the Board of Revenue on the question whether there are trees at any place or places along the said road s

anchor.surface_text: It would seem therefore that the word grove conveys compactness or at any rate substantial compactness to be recognized as a unit by itself which must consist of a group of trees in sufficient number to preclude the land on which they stand from being primarily used for a purpose, such as cultivation, other than as a grove-land.

The appeal is allowed, the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the case is remanded to the High Court to decide the writ petition in the light of the observations hereinabove made after calling a finding from the Board of Revenue on the question whether there are trees at any place or places along the said road s

anchor.surface_text: The language of sec. 5 b  iv  does not require however that the trees needs be fruit bearing trees nor does it require that they should have been planted by human labour or agency. But they must be sufficient in number and so standing in a group as to give them the character of a grove ... Therefore, trees standing in a file on the road sidle intended to furnish shade to the road would not fulfil the requirements of a grove even as understood in ordinary parlance.

The appeal is allowed, the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the case is remanded to the High Court to decide the writ petition in the light of the observations hereinabove made after calling a finding from the Board of Revenue on the question whether there are trees at any place or places along the said road s

anchor.surface_text: Counsel, however, contended that although the trees in question are situate on the road sides along the said road there may at some places be a group or groups of trees sufficiently large in number and closely standing together to preclude that particular area from being used for cultivation or for any other purpose. In that case, be argued, there was nothing in subcl.  iv  to prevent such a cluster of trees from being regarded as a grove. We think there is some force in this argument which requires consideration.
rove even as understood in ordinary parlance. Counsel, however, companytended that although the trees in ques- tion are situate on the road sides alon

anchor.surface_text: Neither the revenue authorities nor the High Court approached the question from this point of view and no inquiry at any stage seems to have been made whether there are at any place or places such group or groups of trees to constitute a grove or groves. All of them appear to have dismissed the appellants claim only because of the fact that the trees stand along the two sides of the road.
